canonical_explanation.text: Coordination compounds (also called complexes) consist of a central metal atom or ion surrounded by molecules or ions called ligands, which are bonded to the metal through coordinate (dative) bonds. Alfred Werner (1893) proposed that metals have two types of valency: primary (ionisable, satisfied by anions, corresponds to oxidation state) and secondary (non-ionisable, satisfied by ligands in a fixed spatial arrangement, corresponds to coordination number). A ligand is a Lewis base that donates at least one lone pair of electrons to the central metal. Ligands can be monodentate (one donor atom, e.g., NH₃, Cl⁻, H₂O), bidentate (two donor atoms, e.g., ethylenediamine (en), oxalate (C₂O₄²⁻)), or polydentate (multiple donor atoms, e.g., EDTA with 6 donor atoms). Ambidentate ligands can bond through either of two donor atoms (e.g., NO₂⁻ through N or O, SCN⁻ through S or N). IUPAC nomenclature follows specific rules: name ligands first (anionic with -o suffix, neutral by their names except aqua for H₂O, ammine for NH₃), then the metal with its oxidation state in Roman numerals. Isomerism in coordination compounds includes structural isomerism (ionisation, linkage, coordination, solvate/hydrate) and stereoisomerism (geometrical/cis-trans and optical). Geometrical isomerism occurs in square planar (cis/trans for [MA₂B₂]) and octahedral complexes. Optical isomerism occurs when the complex is non-superimposable on its mirror image (e.g., [Co(en)₃]³⁺). Valence Bond Theory (VBT) explains bonding using hybridisation of metal orbitals: sp³ (tetrahedral), dsp² (square planar), sp³d² or d²sp³ (octahedral). Inner orbital complexes use (n−1)d orbitals (d²sp³) and are typically low-spin and diamagnetic; outer orbital complexes use nd orbitals (sp³d²) and are typically high-spin and paramagnetic. Crystal Field Theory (CFT) considers ligand-metal interaction as purely electrostatic. In an octahedral field, d orbitals split into t₂g (lower energy: dxy, dyz, dxz) and eg (higher energy: dx²−y², dz²) with energy gap Δo (crystal field splitting energy). In a tetrahedral field, the splitting is reversed and Δt ≈ 4/9 Δo. Strong-field ligands (high Δo) cause pairing (low-spin), while weak-field ligands (low Δo) give high-spin complexes. The spectrochemical series orders ligands by field strength: I⁻ < Br⁻ < Cl⁻ < F⁻ < OH⁻ < C₂O₄²⁻ < H₂O < NH₃ < en < NO₂⁻ < CN⁻ < CO. Crystal Field Stabilisation Energy (CFSE) determines stability and colour. Coordination compounds find applications in medicine (cisplatin as anticancer drug), biological systems (haemoglobin, chlorophyll, vitamin B₁₂), industry (hardness of water estimation with EDTA), and photography (AgBr dissolving in Na₂S₂O₃).
rules: Werner's theory: primary valency = oxidation state (ionisable), secondary valency = coordination number (non-ionisable, directional).
Ligand naming: anionic ligands end in -o (chlorido, cyanido, hydroxido); NH₃ = ammine, H₂O = aqua, CO = carbonyl, NO = nitrosyl.
In IUPAC names, ligands are listed alphabetically, metal oxidation state in Roman numerals, and -ate suffix if the complex ion is anionic.
EDTA is a hexadentate ligand (6 donor atoms: 2N + 4O), forming very stable chelate complexes.
Ionisation isomers give different ions in solution (e.g., [Co(NH₃)₅Br]SO₄ vs [Co(NH₃)₅SO₄]Br).
Linkage isomers differ in the donor atom of an ambidentate ligand (e.g., M-NO₂ nitro vs M-ONO nitrito).
cis-trans isomerism: in square planar [MA₂B₂], cis has identical ligands adjacent, trans has them opposite.
Optical isomers are non-superimposable mirror images; [Co(en)₃]³⁺ shows optical isomerism.
In VBT, d²sp³ hybridisation uses inner d orbitals (low-spin/strong-field), sp³d² uses outer d orbitals (high-spin/weak-field).
In CFT, octahedral splitting: t₂g (3 orbitals, −0.4Δo each) and eg (2 orbitals, +0.6Δo each).
Spectrochemical series: I⁻ < Br⁻ < Cl⁻ < F⁻ < OH⁻ < C₂O₄²⁻ < H₂O < NH₃ < en < NO₂⁻ < CN⁻ < CO.
Cisplatin [PtCl₂(NH₃)₂] (cis isomer) is an anticancer drug; the trans isomer has no anticancer activity.

questions.question_text: In Werner's theory, the secondary valency of a metal corresponds to:

options.text: The coordination number (number of ligands directly bonded to the metal)
The oxidation state of the metal
The number of electrons in the d orbital

questions.explanation_correct: Werner proposed that metals have two types of valencies. The secondary valency is non-ionisable, directional, and represents the coordination number — the number of ligands directly attached to the central metal atom/ion. These are satisfied by neutral molecules or anions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Counter ions satisfy the primary valency (ionisable valency). Oxidation state is the primary valency. The number of d electrons is an electronic property, not a valency concept in Werner's theory.

questions.question_text: A monodentate ligand is one that:

options.text: Donates two pairs of electrons to the metal
Donates one lone pair of electrons through a single donor atom

questions.explanation_correct: A monodentate ligand has a single donor atom and donates one lone pair of electrons to the central metal ion. Examples include NH₃ (N donor), Cl⁻ (Cl donor), H₂O (O donor), and CN⁻ (C donor).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Donating two pairs would be characteristic of a bidentate ligand (though each pair comes from a different donor atom). Bridging ligands can be mono- or polydentate. A ligand must have at least one lone pair to coordinate.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of [Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃ is:
questions.explanation_correct: Following IUPAC rules: ligands are named first (hexa + ammine = hexaammine), followed by the metal (cobalt) with oxidation state in parentheses (III). The counter ion (chloride) comes after. Since the complex ion is cationic, the metal name is not modified. Answer: hexaamminecobalt(III) chloride.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B does not follow correct IUPAC order (ligands before metal). Option C incorrectly includes the counter ions as ligands. Option D uses the -ate suffix, which is only for anionic complex ions.

questions.question_text: An ambidentate ligand is one that:

options.text: Has two donor atoms and both bind simultaneously to the same metal
Can bind through either of two different donor atoms, but only one at a time
Can bind to two different metals simultaneously

questions.explanation_correct: An ambidentate ligand has two potential donor atoms but can coordinate through only one at a time. Examples: NO₂⁻ can bind through N (nitro, –NO₂) or through O (nitrito, –ONO); SCN⁻ can bind through S (thiocyanato) or through N (isothiocyanato).
questions.explanation_incorrect: If both donor atoms bind simultaneously to the same metal, it would be a bidentate ligand (chelating). Binding to two different metals is a bridging ligand. Ambidentate ligands have two possible donor atoms but use only one.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of K₃[Fe(CN)₆] is:
questions.explanation_correct: The complex ion [Fe(CN)₆]³⁻ is anionic. For anionic complexes, the metal name takes the -ate suffix (iron → ferrate). The ligand CN⁻ is named cyanido (6 of them → hexacyanido). Fe oxidation state: x + 6(−1) = −3, so x = +3. Full name: potassium hexacyanidoferrate(III).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A omits the -ate suffix required for anionic complexes. Option C uses 'tri-' for the counter ion, which is not standard IUPAC. Option D is the common name, not the IUPAC name.

questions.question_text: The coordination number and oxidation state of Co in [CoCl₂(en)₂]⁺ are:
questions.explanation_correct: en (ethylenediamine) is bidentate, providing 2 donor atoms each. With 2 en ligands = 4 donor atoms + 2 Cl⁻ = 6 donor atoms total. So coordination number = 6. For oxidation state: x + 2(−1) + 2(0) = +1, so x = +3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coordination number counts donor atoms, not ligands. With 2 bidentate en (4 donors) + 2 Cl⁻ (2 donors) = 6. The charge balance gives +3, not +2.

questions.question_text: EDTA is a hexadentate ligand because it has:
questions.explanation_correct: EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) has 6 donor atoms: 2 nitrogen atoms (from the two amine groups) and 4 oxygen atoms (one from each of the four carboxylate groups). This allows EDTA to wrap around a metal ion and form a very stable chelate complex.
questions.explanation_incorrect: EDTA does not have 6 nitrogen atoms or 6 oxygen atoms alone. The combination is 2N + 4O = 6 donor atoms, making it hexadentate.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of [Pt(NH₃)₂Cl(NO₂)] is:
questions.explanation_correct: Following IUPAC nomenclature: list ligands alphabetically: ammine (×2 = diammine), chlorido (Cl⁻), nitrito-N (NO₂⁻ bonded through N). The metal is platinum with oxidation state: x + 0 + (−1) + (−1) = 0, so x = +2. The complex is neutral, so no -ate suffix. Name: diamminechloridonitrito-N-platinum(II).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B uses 'nitro' which is an older convention; current IUPAC uses 'nitrito-N' to specify the donor atom. Option C uses older 'chloro' instead of 'chlorido'. Option D incorrectly uses -ate suffix for a neutral complex.

questions.question_text: The chelate effect refers to the observation that:

options.text: Complexes with polydentate (chelating) ligands are more stable than those with equivalent monodentate ligands
Chelate ligands always cause low-spin configurations
Chelate complexes cannot undergo substitution reactions

questions.explanation_correct: The chelate effect is the enhanced stability of complexes containing chelating (polydentate) ligands compared to complexes with an equivalent number of monodentate ligands. For example, [Ni(en)₃]²⁺ is much more stable than [Ni(NH₃)₆]²⁺. The extra stability arises from the favourable entropy change when one chelating ligand replaces multiple monodentate ligands.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chelate complexes can be coloured. The chelate effect is about thermodynamic stability, not spin state. Chelate complexes can undergo substitution reactions, though more slowly.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a bidentate ligand?
questions.explanation_correct: Ethylenediamine (H₂N–CH₂–CH₂–NH₂) is a bidentate ligand with two nitrogen donor atoms. Both nitrogen atoms can simultaneously coordinate to the same metal ion, forming a five-membered chelate ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NH₃, Cl⁻, and H₂O are all monodentate ligands with only one donor atom each. Only ethylenediamine has two donor atoms that can bind simultaneously.

questions.question_text: In the complex [Cr(NH₃)₄Cl₂]⁺, the oxidation state of chromium is:
questions.explanation_correct: NH₃ is a neutral ligand (charge = 0), Cl⁻ has charge −1. The overall charge is +1. So: x + 4(0) + 2(−1) = +1, giving x − 2 = +1, x = +3. Chromium is in the +3 oxidation state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the charge balance: x − 2 = +1 gives x = +3. The values +1, +2, and +4 do not satisfy the charge balance equation.

questions.question_text: Ionisation isomers are coordination compounds that:

options.text: Have different geometric arrangements of ligands
Produce different ions in solution due to exchange of ligands between the coordination sphere and the counter ion
Are mirror images of each other
Differ in the donor atom of an ambidentate ligand

questions.explanation_correct: Ionisation isomers differ in which ions are inside the coordination sphere versus outside as counter ions. For example, [Co(NH₃)₅Br]SO₄ gives Br⁻ in the coordination sphere and SO₄²⁻ as counter ion, while [Co(NH₃)₅SO₄]Br has SO₄²⁻ in the coordination sphere and Br⁻ as counter ion. They produce different ions in solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Different geometric arrangements describe geometrical isomers. Mirror images describe optical isomers. Different donor atoms describe linkage isomers. Ionisation isomers differ in the distribution of ions between coordination sphere and outside.

questions.question_text: Linkage isomerism arises when:

options.text: The ligand can coordinate through different donor atoms
Ligands exchange between coordination sphere and counter ion
Water molecules are present in different positions
The complex has different geometric arrangements

questions.explanation_correct: Linkage isomerism occurs when an ambidentate ligand coordinates through different donor atoms. For example, NO₂⁻ can bond through nitrogen (nitro isomer, M–NO₂) or through oxygen (nitrito isomer, M–ONO). Similarly, SCN⁻ can bond through S (thiocyanato) or N (isothiocyanato).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Exchange between coordination sphere and counter ion is ionisation isomerism. Water in different positions is hydrate/solvate isomerism. Different geometric arrangements is geometrical isomerism.

questions.question_text: Which of the following square planar complexes shows geometrical isomerism?
questions.explanation_correct: [Pt(NH₃)₂Cl₂] has the general formula [MA₂B₂] in a square planar geometry, which can exist as cis (both NH₃ adjacent, both Cl adjacent) and trans (NH₃ opposite each other, Cl opposite each other) isomers. The cis form is cisplatin (an anticancer drug).
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Pt(NH₃)₄]²⁺ and [PtCl₄]²⁻ have all identical ligands (MA₄ type), so no geometrical isomerism. [Pt(NH₃)₃Cl]⁺ has 3 of one type and 1 of another (MA₃B), which does not show cis-trans isomerism in square planar geometry.

questions.question_text: Which of the following octahedral complexes can show optical isomerism?
questions.explanation_correct: [Co(en)₃]³⁺ has three bidentate en ligands arranged around the cobalt in an octahedral geometry. This complex has no plane of symmetry and is non-superimposable on its mirror image, making it optically active with d and l (Δ and Λ) enantiomers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Co(NH₃)₆]³⁺ and [CoCl₆]³⁻ have all identical monodentate ligands and possess planes of symmetry. [Co(NH₃)₅Cl]²⁺ has a plane of symmetry and is superimposable on its mirror image. Only [Co(en)₃]³⁺ is chiral.

questions.question_text: [Co(NH₃)₅(NO₂)]²⁺ and [Co(NH₃)₅(ONO)]²⁺ are examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: These are linkage isomers. The ambidentate ligand NO₂⁻ coordinates through the nitrogen atom (nitro, –NO₂) in the first complex and through the oxygen atom (nitrito, –ONO) in the second. The ligand is the same (NO₂⁻), but the bonding atom differs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Geometrical isomers differ in spatial arrangement of different ligands. Ionisation isomers differ in which ions are in the coordination sphere. Optical isomers are non-superimposable mirror images. These complexes differ in the donor atom of NO₂⁻, hence they are linkage isomers.

questions.question_text: The complex [CoCl₂(en)₂]⁺ can show both geometrical and optical isomerism. The cis isomer shows optical isomerism because:

options.text: It has a plane of symmetry
It is non-superimposable on its mirror image (lacks a plane of symmetry)

questions.explanation_correct: The cis-[CoCl₂(en)₂]⁺ isomer has no plane of symmetry, making it chiral. Its mirror image is not superimposable on itself, giving rise to d and l enantiomers. The trans isomer, however, has a plane of symmetry and is optically inactive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Having a plane of symmetry would make it achiral (optically inactive). It does not have all identical ligands. It is octahedral, not tetrahedral. The chirality arises from the lack of symmetry in the cis arrangement.

questions.question_text: [CrCl₂(H₂O)₄]Cl·2H₂O and [CrCl(H₂O)₅]Cl₂·H₂O are examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrate (solvate) isomers differ in whether water molecules are inside the coordination sphere (bound to the metal as ligands) or outside (as water of crystallisation). In the first compound, 4 H₂O are ligands and 2 are outside. In the second, 5 H₂O are ligands and 1 is outside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Linkage isomers differ in donor atoms. Ionisation isomers exchange ions between inside and outside the complex. Coordination isomers occur between cationic and anionic complex ions. These compounds differ specifically in the position of water molecules.

questions.question_text: How many geometrical isomers can an octahedral complex [MA₂B₂C₂] exhibit?
questions.explanation_correct: An octahedral complex [MA₂B₂C₂] can have 5 geometrical isomers. The possible arrangements depend on which pairs of identical ligands are cis (adjacent) or trans (opposite) to each other. There are 5 distinct arrangements: all-cis, all-trans, and various mixed cis-trans combinations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2 isomers would be for a simpler [MA₂B₂] square planar case. 3 is for [MA₃B₃] octahedral (fac/mer). 6 would overcount as some arrangements are equivalent. The correct count for [MA₂B₂C₂] octahedral is 5.

questions.question_text: The cis and trans isomers of [Pt(NH₃)₂Cl₂] differ in:

options.text: The spatial arrangement of ligands around the central metal

questions.explanation_correct: Cis and trans isomers have the same molecular formula, same ligands, and same oxidation state of the metal. They differ only in the spatial arrangement: in the cis form, identical ligands are adjacent (90°), while in the trans form, they are opposite (180°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The molecular formula is identical for both isomers. The oxidation state (+2) is the same. The ligands (NH₃ and Cl⁻) are the same. Only the geometric arrangement differs.

questions.question_text: Coordination isomerism is possible in compounds that have:

options.text: Both cationic and anionic complex ions

questions.explanation_correct: Coordination isomerism occurs in compounds containing both a cationic and an anionic complex ion, where ligands can interchange between the two. For example, [Co(NH₃)₆][Cr(CN)₆] and [Cr(NH₃)₆][Co(CN)₆] are coordination isomers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single cationic complex alone cannot show coordination isomerism. Monodentate ligands are not a requirement — the key is having two complex ions. Ambidentate ligands lead to linkage isomerism, not coordination isomerism.

questions.question_text: According to Valence Bond Theory (VBT), the hybridisation of the central metal ion in a tetrahedral complex is:
questions.explanation_correct: In VBT, a tetrahedral complex involves sp³ hybridisation of the metal orbitals (one s + three p orbitals). The four hybrid orbitals are directed towards the corners of a tetrahedron, and ligands donate electron pairs into these orbitals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sp² gives trigonal planar geometry (3 orbitals). dsp² gives square planar geometry. d²sp³ gives octahedral geometry. Tetrahedral complexes use sp³ hybridisation.

questions.question_text: In Crystal Field Theory (CFT), the d orbitals of a metal ion in an octahedral field split into:

options.text: Two sets: t₂g (dxy, dyz, dxz) at lower energy and eg (dx²−y², dz²) at higher energy
Two sets: eg at lower energy and t₂g at higher energy

questions.explanation_correct: In an octahedral crystal field, the five d orbitals split into two groups: the t₂g set (dxy, dyz, dxz) at lower energy (directed between the axes, away from ligands) and the eg set (dx²−y², dz²) at higher energy (directed along the axes, towards ligands). The energy difference is Δo.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B reverses the energy order (that applies to tetrahedral fields). The orbitals split into two groups, not five separate levels. Splitting always occurs in the presence of ligands.

questions.question_text: The spectrochemical series arranges ligands in order of their:
questions.explanation_correct: The spectrochemical series arranges ligands in order of increasing crystal field splitting energy (Δ). Ligands on the left (I⁻, Br⁻) are weak-field ligands producing small Δ, while those on the right (CN⁻, CO) are strong-field ligands producing large Δ.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ligand size does not directly determine position in the spectrochemical series. Coordination number is determined by the metal, not ligand field strength. Charge alone does not determine field strength (e.g., NH₃ is neutral but a strong-field ligand).

questions.question_text: According to CFT, [CoF₆]³⁻ is a high-spin complex while [Co(CN)₆]³⁻ is a low-spin complex because:

options.text: F⁻ is a strong-field ligand and CN⁻ is a weak-field ligand
F⁻ is a weak-field ligand (small Δo) favouring electron spreading, while CN⁻ is a strong-field ligand (large Δo) favouring electron pairing
Co has different oxidation states in the two complexes
CN⁻ is a larger ligand than F⁻

questions.explanation_correct: F⁻ is a weak-field ligand (low Δo), so the energy gap between t₂g and eg is small. Electrons prefer to occupy higher energy eg orbitals rather than pair up in t₂g (since pairing energy > Δo), giving a high-spin complex. CN⁻ is a strong-field ligand (high Δo), making it energetically favourable for electrons to pair in t₂g rather than go to eg (Δo > pairing energy), giving a low-spin complex.
questions.explanation_incorrect: F⁻ is weak-field, not strong-field (it appears on the left side of the spectrochemical series). Both complexes have Co³⁺ (d⁶). The size of the ligand is not the determining factor; the field strength (Δo) is.

questions.question_text: In VBT, an inner orbital octahedral complex uses which type of hybridisation?
questions.explanation_correct: Inner orbital complexes use d²sp³ hybridisation, involving two (n−1)d, one ns, and three np orbitals. These complexes typically form when strong-field ligands force d electrons to pair up, freeing two inner d orbitals for hybridisation. They are usually low-spin and diamagnetic or have fewer unpaired electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sp³d² is outer orbital hybridisation using nd orbitals (high-spin). sp³ is tetrahedral. dsp² is square planar. Inner orbital octahedral complexes specifically use d²sp³.

questions.question_text: Which of the following ligands would cause the largest crystal field splitting?
questions.explanation_correct: According to the spectrochemical series: I⁻ < Br⁻ < Cl⁻ < F⁻ < OH⁻ < C₂O₄²⁻ < H₂O < NH₃ < en < NO₂⁻ < CN⁻ < CO. CN⁻ is a strong-field ligand near the top of the series and produces the largest crystal field splitting (Δ) among the given options.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I⁻ is the weakest field ligand listed. F⁻ is relatively weak-field among halides but still far below CN⁻. H₂O is moderate. CN⁻ produces the largest Δ.

questions.question_text: The CFSE (Crystal Field Stabilisation Energy) for a d⁶ ion in a strong octahedral field is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a strong octahedral field, d⁶ adopts a low-spin configuration: t₂g⁶ eg⁰. CFSE = 6 × (−0.4Δo) + 0 × (+0.6Δo) = −2.4Δo. However, pairing 3 pairs of electrons requires 3P pairing energy, but since the free ion already has 1 pair, the extra pairing energy is 2P. Net CFSE = −2.4Δo + 2P.
questions.explanation_incorrect: −0.4Δo would apply to d¹. −2.4Δo does not account for pairing energy. −1.6Δo applies to d⁴ high-spin or d⁸. The correct CFSE for low-spin d⁶ includes the pairing energy correction.

questions.question_text: In a tetrahedral crystal field, the energy of e orbitals (dz², dx²−y²) is lower than that of t₂ orbitals (dxy, dyz, dxz). This is because:

options.text: The e orbitals point directly at the ligands in a tetrahedral field
The t₂ orbitals are closer to the ligands in a tetrahedral arrangement, causing more repulsion and higher energy
Tetrahedral splitting is the same as octahedral splitting
The ligands in a tetrahedral field are arranged along the axes

questions.explanation_correct: In a tetrahedral field, the ligands are positioned at alternate corners of a cube (not along the axes). The t₂ orbitals (dxy, dyz, dxz) point towards the edges of the cube, closer to the ligands, experiencing more repulsion and thus having higher energy. The e orbitals (dz², dx²−y²) point along the axes, farther from the tetrahedral ligands, and have lower energy. This is the reverse of octahedral splitting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The e orbitals point along axes, which are farther from tetrahedral ligand positions. Tetrahedral splitting is reversed from octahedral. The ligands in a tetrahedral field are NOT along the axes but at alternate cube corners.

questions.question_text: The relationship between tetrahedral splitting (Δt) and octahedral splitting (Δo) for the same metal and ligands is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Tetrahedral crystal field splitting (Δt) is approximately 4/9 of the octahedral splitting (Δo): Δt ≈ (4/9)Δo. This is because in a tetrahedral field there are only 4 ligands (vs 6 in octahedral) and the ligands do not directly face any d orbital. The smaller Δt explains why tetrahedral complexes are almost always high-spin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Δt is not equal to Δo — it is significantly smaller. Δt is not larger than Δo. The 4/9 ratio accounts for fewer ligands and indirect orientation in tetrahedral symmetry.

questions.question_text: The colour of [Ti(H₂O)₆]³⁺ is purple because:

options.text: The single d electron in Ti³⁺ (d¹) undergoes a t₂g → eg transition absorbing yellow-green light, and the complementary purple colour is transmitted
Ti³⁺ emits purple light from f orbitals

questions.explanation_correct: Ti³⁺ has a d¹ configuration. In the octahedral crystal field of [Ti(H₂O)₆]³⁺, the single d electron occupies a t₂g orbital. When it absorbs light corresponding to the energy gap Δo (which falls in the yellow-green region, ~500 nm), it transitions to an eg orbital. The complementary colour — purple — is what we observe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ti³⁺ is d¹, not d⁰. Water is a colourless ligand. There are no f orbitals involved. The purple colour results from d-d transitions absorbing yellow-green light.

questions.question_text: A complex with d²sp³ hybridisation would be:
questions.explanation_correct: d²sp³ hybridisation involves 2 inner d + 1 s + 3 p orbitals = 6 hybrid orbitals, giving an octahedral geometry. It is called an inner orbital complex because the d orbitals used are from the (n−1) shell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tetrahedral is sp³. Square planar is dsp². Trigonal bipyramidal is sp³d. d²sp³ specifically gives octahedral geometry using inner d orbitals.

questions.question_text: [NiCl₄]²⁻ is tetrahedral while [Ni(CN)₄]²⁻ is square planar. This difference is because:

options.text: Ni has different oxidation states in the two complexes
CN⁻ is a strong-field ligand that forces pairing of d electrons, allowing dsp² hybridisation (square planar), while Cl⁻ is a weak-field ligand giving sp³ hybridisation (tetrahedral)
CN⁻ has more electrons than Cl⁻

questions.explanation_correct: In both complexes, Ni is in the +2 state (d⁸). With Cl⁻ (weak-field), electrons are not forced to pair, and sp³ hybridisation gives a tetrahedral geometry. With CN⁻ (strong-field), electrons pair up in the lower d orbitals, freeing one d orbital for dsp² hybridisation, resulting in a square planar geometry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ni is +2 in both complexes. Ligand size is not the determining factor. The number of electrons in the ligand is irrelevant. The key difference is the field strength: CN⁻ (strong) causes pairing and square planar geometry, while Cl⁻ (weak) gives tetrahedral.

questions.question_text: The number of unpaired electrons in [Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻ is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fe²⁺ is d⁶. CN⁻ is a strong-field ligand (high Δo), so the complex is low-spin with the configuration t₂g⁶ eg⁰. All 6 d electrons are paired in the three t₂g orbitals, giving 0 unpaired electrons. The complex is diamagnetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4 unpaired electrons would correspond to high-spin d⁶ (t₂g⁴ eg²). 2 would be incorrect for either configuration. 5 would correspond to d⁵ high-spin. CN⁻ is a strong-field ligand, forcing all electrons to pair in t₂g.

questions.question_text: Cisplatin, the anticancer drug, has the formula:
questions.explanation_correct: Cisplatin is the cis isomer of [PtCl₂(NH₃)₂], where the two Cl⁻ ligands are adjacent to each other and the two NH₃ ligands are also adjacent. The cis geometry is essential for its anticancer activity, as it allows cross-linking of DNA strands. The trans isomer does not have anticancer activity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The trans isomer (transplatin) is inactive as an anticancer drug. [Pt(NH₃)₄]Cl₂ has no Cl in the coordination sphere. K₂[PtCl₄] is potassium tetrachloroplatinate(II). Only cis-[PtCl₂(NH₃)₂] is cisplatin.

questions.question_text: The metal present in haemoglobin is:
questions.explanation_correct: Haemoglobin contains iron (Fe²⁺) at the centre of a porphyrin ring (a coordination complex). The Fe²⁺ ion coordinates with the four nitrogen atoms of the porphyrin and one nitrogen from the imidazole of histidine. The sixth coordination site binds O₂ for transport in blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cu is found in haemocyanin (in some invertebrates). Mg is found in chlorophyll. Zn is found in carbonic anhydrase. Haemoglobin specifically contains iron.

questions.question_text: EDTA is used in the estimation of hardness of water because:

options.text: It precipitates Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions
It forms very stable chelate complexes with Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions
It oxidises Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ to higher oxidation states
It reduces Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ to metals

questions.explanation_correct: EDTA is a hexadentate ligand that forms very stable 1:1 chelate complexes with Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions. In complexometric titration, EDTA is added until all Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ are complexed, using Eriochrome Black T (EBT) as an indicator. The high stability constant of the EDTA complex ensures a sharp endpoint.
questions.explanation_incorrect: EDTA does not precipitate, oxidise, or reduce these ions. It forms soluble chelate complexes, which is the basis of its use in volumetric analysis of water hardness.

questions.question_text: The metal present in chlorophyll is:
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorophyll contains a magnesium (Mg²⁺) ion at the centre of a porphyrin ring. The Mg²⁺ coordinates with four nitrogen atoms of the porphyrin. Chlorophyll is responsible for absorbing light energy in photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fe is in haemoglobin. Cu is in haemocyanin. Mn is involved in the oxygen-evolving complex but not in the chlorophyll structure itself. Chlorophyll contains magnesium.

questions.question_text: In photography, AgBr is dissolved using Na₂S₂O₃ (hypo). This works because:

options.text: Na₂S₂O₃ forms a soluble complex [Ag(S₂O₃)₂]³⁻ with Ag⁺ ions

questions.explanation_correct: In the fixing step of photography, unexposed AgBr is removed from the photographic film by dissolving it in Na₂S₂O₃ (hypo/sodium thiosulphate). The thiosulphate ion acts as a ligand and forms the soluble complex ion [Ag(S₂O₃)₂]³⁻: AgBr + 2Na₂S₂O₃ → Na₃[Ag(S₂O₃)₂] + NaBr.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na₂S₂O₃ does not reduce AgBr to metallic silver (that is done by light and developing agents). It does not oxidise Br⁻. It dissolves AgBr, not precipitates it. The mechanism is complex formation.

questions.question_text: Vitamin B₁₂ is a coordination compound containing which metal?
questions.explanation_correct: Vitamin B₁₂ (cyanocobalamin) is a coordination compound of cobalt. It contains a cobalt(III) ion coordinated to a corrin ring (similar to porphyrin), a cyanide ligand, and a 5,6-dimethylbenzimidazole nucleotide. It is essential for red blood cell formation and neurological function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is in haemoglobin and myoglobin. Zinc is in carbonic anhydrase and carboxypeptidase. Copper is in haemocyanin. Vitamin B₁₂ specifically contains cobalt.

questions.question_text: Wilkinson's catalyst, used for homogeneous hydrogenation of alkenes, is:
questions.explanation_correct: Wilkinson's catalyst is chloridotris(triphenylphosphine)rhodium(I), [RhCl(PPh₃)₃]. It is a highly effective homogeneous catalyst for the hydrogenation of alkenes at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Its square planar geometry allows the substrate and H₂ to coordinate to the metal centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [PtCl₂(NH₃)₂] is cisplatin (anticancer drug). [Ni(CO)₄] is formed in the Mond process. [Fe(CO)₅] is iron pentacarbonyl. Wilkinson's catalyst is specifically [RhCl(PPh₃)₃].

questions.question_text: The EAN (effective atomic number) rule states that the total number of electrons around the central metal atom in a stable complex tends to equal the atomic number of the next noble gas. For [Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻, the EAN of Fe is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fe²⁺ has 24 electrons. Each CN⁻ donates 2 electrons, and there are 6 CN⁻ ligands: 6 × 2 = 12 electrons donated. EAN = 24 + 12 = 36, which equals the atomic number of krypton (Kr). This satisfies the EAN rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 54 (Xe) would require far more electrons. 18 (Ar) is too few. 28 does not correspond to any noble gas. Fe²⁺ (24 electrons) + 12 donated electrons = 36 (Kr).

questions.question_text: A limitation of Valence Bond Theory in explaining coordination compounds is that:

options.text: It can explain the geometry of complexes
It cannot quantitatively explain the colour and spectra of complexes
It accurately predicts all magnetic properties

questions.explanation_correct: VBT explains hybridisation, geometry, and qualitative magnetic behaviour. However, it cannot quantitatively explain the colour, absorption spectra, or thermodynamic stability of coordination compounds. It also cannot explain the spectrochemical series or predict the exact magnetic moments in many cases. CFT and Ligand Field Theory address these limitations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: VBT can explain geometry (that is its strength). It does not always accurately predict magnetic properties (e.g., it fails for some paramagnetic complexes). It does not explain the spectrochemical series.

questions.question_text: The number of geometrical isomers for an octahedral complex [MA₃B₃] is:
questions.explanation_correct: An octahedral [MA₃B₃] complex has two geometrical isomers: fac (facial, where three identical ligands occupy one face of the octahedron) and mer (meridional, where three identical ligands are in the same plane including two trans positions and one cis). No other distinct arrangements are possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are exactly 2 geometrical isomers (fac and mer), not 1, 3, or 4. Additional arrangements are equivalent to one of these two by symmetry.

questions.question_text: In CFT, a d³ ion in an octahedral field has the electron configuration:
questions.explanation_correct: With 3 d electrons, each electron occupies one of the three t₂g orbitals (following Hund's rule), giving t₂g³ eg⁰. This is the same whether the field is strong or weak, because 3 electrons can occupy 3 separate t₂g orbitals without any need for pairing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For d³, electrons first fill the lower-energy t₂g set. Since there are exactly 3 t₂g orbitals and 3 electrons, each goes into a separate orbital. No electrons go to eg until t₂g is filled or the pairing energy becomes relevant.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an application of coordination compounds?

options.text: AgBr dissolution in photography using Na₂S₂O₃

questions.explanation_correct: Combustion of hydrocarbons is a purely chemical (organic/inorganic) reaction involving oxidation and does not involve coordination chemistry. EDTA titrations, cisplatin therapy, and photographic fixing are all well-known applications of coordination compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: EDTA for hardness estimation involves chelate complex formation. Cisplatin is a coordination compound used as a drug. Na₂S₂O₃ forms a coordination complex with Ag⁺. Only combustion of hydrocarbons is unrelated to coordination chemistry.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of [CrCl₂(en)₂]Cl is:
questions.explanation_correct: IUPAC rules: list ligands alphabetically. 'bis(ethylenediamine)' comes before 'dichlorido' alphabetically (b before d). Metal: chromium. Oxidation state: x + 0 + 2(−1) = +1, so x = +3 → chromium(III). Counter ion: chloride. Full name: bis(ethylenediamine)dichloridochromium(III) chloride.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A lists ligands in incorrect alphabetical order (dichloro before bis). Option B has a naming issue. Option D does not follow IUPAC ligand-first convention. Alphabetical order of ligands is mandatory in IUPAC nomenclature.

questions.question_text: The magnetic moment of [Mn(CN)₆]⁴⁻ is 1.73 BM, indicating the number of unpaired electrons is:
questions.explanation_correct: μ = √(n(n+2)) BM. For μ = 1.73 BM: 1.73 = √(n(n+2)). Squaring: 3 = n(n+2). n = 1 satisfies this (1×3 = 3). Mn²⁺ is d⁵. With CN⁻ (strong-field), the low-spin configuration is t₂g⁵ eg⁰, giving 1 unpaired electron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0 unpaired electrons would give μ = 0 (diamagnetic). 3 would give μ = 3.87 BM. 5 would give μ = 5.92 BM. The value 1.73 BM corresponds exactly to 1 unpaired electron.

questions.question_text: Optical isomers are molecules that are:

options.text: Different in the number of ligands

questions.explanation_correct: Optical isomers (enantiomers) are non-superimposable mirror images of each other. They have identical physical and chemical properties except for the direction in which they rotate the plane of polarised light (dextro/d or laevo/l) and their interaction with other chiral molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If identical to their mirror image, the molecule is achiral (not optically active). Optical isomers have the same molecular formula. They have the same number and types of ligands — only the spatial arrangement differs.

questions.question_text: Carbon monoxide poisoning occurs because CO:

options.text: Reacts with water in the blood to form carbonic acid
Forms a very stable complex with haemoglobin (carboxyhaemoglobin), preventing O₂ binding
Reduces Fe²⁺ in haemoglobin to Fe⁰

questions.explanation_correct: CO is a strong-field ligand that binds to the Fe²⁺ in haemoglobin approximately 200-250 times more strongly than O₂. Once CO occupies the O₂ binding site, it forms carboxyhaemoglobin (HbCO), which is very stable and prevents normal oxygen transport. This leads to oxygen deprivation and can be fatal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO does not form carbonic acid (that would be CO₂). CO does not reduce Fe²⁺ to metallic iron. Methaemoglobin involves oxidation of Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺, which is caused by other agents (nitrites, etc.), not CO. CO toxicity is due to its strong binding as a ligand.
